I disagree with the claim that school librarians are expendable. While it's true that school teachers do play an important role in educating students, libraries and librarians offer many unique and valuable contributions to a school's educational environment.

Firstly, librarians are trained professionals who specialize in helping students navigate and understand information. They can offer guidance on things like research strategies, citation formats, and how to evaluate the accuracy and credibility of sources. This is a crucial skill set that teachers may not have the necessary training or time to provide to their students.

Additionally, librarians are able to curate and maintain a variety of materials and resources that teachers may not have access to or the time to gather themselves. This includes things like books, databases and other reference materials, as well as computers and other technology that students can use to enhance their learning experiences.

Lastly, libraries offer a quiet and focused environment where students can study and work on their own or collaboratively with classmates. In many cases, this is not something that can be replicated in a classroom setting, where distractions and interruptions are more prevalent.

For these reasons, I believe that school librarians are essential members of a school's educational community and are certainly not expendable.

While it is true that technology has changed the landscape of education and increased access to information, I do not agree that school librarians are expendable. In fact, I believe that technology has actually increased the importance of librarians in a school community.

While there is indeed an abundance of information available online, not all of it is reliable or appropriate for academic use. Librarians have the expertise to navigate the online world and to evaluate and select the most credible and relevant resources for students and teachers. Additionally, while digital resources have made many things more accessible, they have also created new challenges in terms of organizing and managing information. Librarians have the skills to manage, curate, and organize the growing amount of digital information so that it is accessible and useful to students and teachers.

Finally, libraries are more than just collections of resources - they are also places where students can engage in meaningful learning experiences and develop a love for reading and lifelong learning. Librarians can provide programming that promotes literacy, creativity, and critical thinking, which are important skills for success in any subject area.

In conclusion, while technology has certainly changed the way we think about information access and research, I argue that school librarians are still essential members of a school community and are definitely not expendable.
